channel.title: NYT > Most Recent Headlines
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: President Trump Says He Will Release His M.R.I. Results
item.description: President Trump said he would release the results of a recent magnetic resonance imaging scan, which he called “perfect.” When asked what part of the body was scanned, Mr. Trump replied that he didn’t know.
item.dc:creator: Axel Boada

item.title: Hundreds Killed After Cyclone in Sri Lanka, Officials Say
item.description: Sri Lanka’s president said the country was dealing with the “largest and most challenging natural disaster” in its history after Cyclone Ditwah unleashed a deadly wave of flooding and submerged entire towns.
item.dc:creator: Nader Ibrahim

media:content.media:description: Partially submerged houses in floodwater on the outskirts of Colombo.

item.title: Quick and Easy Hoisin Garlic Noodles Recipe
item.description: Specifically these fast and friendly hoisin garlic noodles, which welcome whatever toppings you’d like.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Clark

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Monica Pierini.
media:content.media:description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s hoisin garlic noodles.

item.title: For ‘No Tax on Tips,’ the I.R.S. Gets Intimate
item.description: The Trump administration wants to exclude earnings from “pornographic activity” from a new tax break for tips. Will the I.R.S. know it when it sees it?
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: Two Galleries Form New Art Prize
item.description: The FLAG Art Foundation in New York and Serpentine in London have established a 1 million British pound award for five artists.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Serpentine x FLAG Art Foundation Prize

media:content.media:description: From left: Patti Harris; Hans Ulrich Obrist; Amanda Fuhrman; Glenn Fuhrman, the founder of the FLAG Art Foundation; Bettina Korek, chief executive of Serpentine; and Michael Bloomberg.

item.title: Do You Remember When These Authors Appeared in the Movies of Their Novels?
item.description: Some writers have followed their words onto the screen. Try this short quiz to see if you recall five of those cameo scenes.
item.dc:creator: J. D. Biersdorfer

item.title: College Students Choosing A.I. Majors Over Computer Science
item.description: At M.I.T., a new program called “artificial intelligence and decision-making” is now the second-most-popular undergraduate major.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: A Surprise When Your Package Arrives: You Have to Pay the Tariff
item.description: The end of a tariff exemption on goods worth $800 or less has left some U.S. shoppers with an extra shipping bill that must be paid before delivery.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis

media:content.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Kim Batten purchased her coat from a Dutch retailer. After it shipped, she learned she’d need to pay over $250 in customs duties.

item.title: Alina Habba, Trump’s Former Lawyer, Is Unlawful U.S. Attorney, Appeals Court Says
item.description: The judges wrote that the Trump administration appeared to have become frustrated by legal and political barriers that have prevented its preferred U.S. attorneys from leading federal prosecutors’ offices.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich and Tracey Tully

media:content.media:description: Monday’s decision affirms a ruling by a federal judge who in August concluded that Ms. Habba had been serving as New Jersey’s U.S. attorney without legal authority since July 1.

item.title: Después del huracán, Jamaica espera el retorno de los turistas
item.description: El turismo representa casi un tercio de la economía de Jamaica, por eso las autoridades se apuran a reabrir decenas de hoteles para salvar la vital temporada de viajes de invierno.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Erin Schaff

media:content.media:description: Kellanie Kerr working by flashlight at a tourist shop this month in Negril, Jamaica.

item.title: Floods in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam Have Killed Over 1,200. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Unusually destructive storms have killed more than 1,200 people across the region and displaced millions in South and Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Muktita Suhartono and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

media:content.media:description: A village affected by a flash flood in Batang Toru, North Sumatra, Indonesia, on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Is Not a War of Attrition
item.description: Victory will belong not to the side with more resources, but to the side with the stronger, more adaptive and unyielding will to win.
item.dc:creator: Dmytro Kuleba

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Demands Netflix Drop 50 Cent Series, Citing New Footage
item.description: The mogul’s lawyers told the streaming service to withdraw a documentary because it was produced by his rival and uses footage they say was “illicitly” acquired.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario

media:content.media:description: Sean Combs is the subject of a new documentary series executive produced by his longtime rival, 50 Cent, that includes footage Mr. Combs commissioned in the days leading up to his 2024 arrest.

item.title: I Made an Offensive Joke. But So Did Everyone Else! Why Did I Get Fired?
item.description: Plus, should you endure a stultifying work life to enable a happy personal life?
item.dc:creator: Max Read

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Possible fader for slug. Sri Lanka is “A Disaster Zone,” as Cyclone Deaths Cross 350
item.description: Possible fader for slug. Sri Lanka is “A Disaster Zone,” as Cyclone Deaths Cross 350

media:content.media:description: A man is carried through flooded streets on the outskirts of Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Sunday.

item.title: Markets Defy the White House
item.description: Volatility has returned to stocks and crypto trading, despite assurances from a top administration official, as investors brace for more data on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount

media:content.media:description: Markets are slipping despite signs of resilient consumer spending.

item.title: OpenAI Takes Stake in Thrive Holdings, a Buyer of Services Firms
item.description: The move by the parent company of ChatGPT is meant to help imbue Thrive Holdings’ accounting and I.T. services companies with artificial intelligence tools.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

media:content.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Sam Altman of OpenAI. The company is betting that taking a stake in Thrive Holdings, which is incubating services companies, will showcase how businesses should adopt artificial intelligence.

item.title: In Egypt, Museums Built of Sand and Salt
item.description: Plus: an unusual late-autumn fruit, an all-local produce store in Hawai‘i and more recommendations from T Magazine.

item.title: Hong Kong Contractors Used Unsafe Netting at Fire Site, Officials Say
item.description: Investigators say contractors wrapped the buildings in substandard scaffolding netting and then sought to hide it from inspectors. The toll from the fire rose to 151.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong and Selam Gebrekidan

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Green netting and bamboo scaffolding are visible on buildings at Wang Fuk Court, the Hong Kong apartment complex engulfed by fire last week.

item.title: Your Drone Questions
item.description: We asked readers of The Morning for their questions about drones. Today, Times journalists answer.
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Kushner
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A drone during a training exercise in Louisiana.

item.title: When Luca Guadagnino Brought Brazilian Modernism to Milan
item.description: High above the cloistered, elegant city, the director turned a friend’s apartment into a moody and tropical oasis.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay and Simon Watson

item.title: The Prettiest Holiday Shoes Come With Bows on Top
item.description: Fancy ribbons add charm to these party accessories.

item.title: How Cotton Candy Won Over the Adults
item.description: Long associated with childhood and county fairs, the food has found its place among a new generation of experimental chefs.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Joseph and Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi

item.title: Un ‘Israel imperial’ en el nuevo Medio Oriente
item.description: Una serie de atentados recientes ilustra la extensión del alcance israelí en la región.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:description: After an Israeli drone strike in Lebanon in September.

item.title: Detrás del empeño de Trump por hacer el salón de baile de la Casa Blanca lo más grande posible
item.description: La visión cada vez más expansiva del presidente ha provocado tensiones con los contratistas. Su arquitecto ha dado un paso atrás mientras Trump gestiona personalmente el proyecto.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:description: Trump ordenó la creación de un salón de baile con capacidad para más del doble de personas que los planes iniciales.

item.title: The Fallout From the National Guard Shooting
item.description: After an Afghan man opened fire on two members of the service in Washington, President Trump ordered a sweeping new crackdown on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Mooj Zadie, Patricia Willens, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Alyssa Moxley and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A photograph of Rahmanullah Lakanwal, right, displayed at a news conference in Washington on Thursday next to images of the two victims.

item.title: Trump Pauses All Asylum Applications, and China’s Fast-Food Brands Make a Play for the U.S.
item.description: Plus, how young is too young for a smartphone?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Kate LoPresti and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration’s pause on asylum decisions was one of the latest restrictive changes to the immigration system after a recent shooting of National Guard members.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Pardon Request Borrows From Trump’s Playbook
item.description: In many ways, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s request mimics how President Trump has assailed his perceived enemies and attacked legal proceedings against him.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. His petition to the country’s president, Isaac Herzog, admitted nothing and expressed no contrition.

item.title: Zelensky Turns to Europe After Talks With U.S. Officials
item.description: Ukraine’s president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday as Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, was traveling to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Paris on Monday as part of a flurry of diplomatic talks to end the war with Russia.

item.title: Inside the Bird-Flu Vaccine Trial for Monk Seals
item.description: After the virus returned to Hawaii this fall, testing the shots in the endangered seal species became urgent.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Loren Elliott

media:content.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: The Most Interesting Wine Books of 2025
item.description: A fascinating history of California wine, a beginner’s handbook, “A Cynic’s Guide” and visits to natural producers in France and England, with recipes
item.dc:creator: Eric Asimov

item.title: Supreme Court Hears Copyright Battle Over Online Music Piracy
item.description: At issue is whether internet providers can be held liable for repeated copyright infringements of users, with potentially billions of dollars on the line.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

media:content.media:description: Several justices said Cox Communication’s “mere knowledge” of illegal downloads was not sufficient to hold the company liable.

item.title: Can I Wear Shearling if I Don’t Want to Wear Fur?
item.description: Celebrities, magazines and retail stores say yes. But are we all fooling ourselves?
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

media:content.media:description: Shearling has become the non-fur fur of fashion.

item.title: Farewell to the Beloved Friend in My Window
item.description: Winter won’t hold forever, and when it comes, a spider will disappear from the corner where she has made her home.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Best Clothing Stores in the Country
item.description: We selected the 50 best clothing stores in the United States. Five reporters from The New York Times Style section describe how we chose them.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz, Misty White Sidell, Gina Cherelus, Alex Vadukul, Sadiba Hasan, Gabby Bulgarelli, Sutton Raphael, Jillian Eugenios, Thomas Vollkommer and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Donate This Holiday Season: Eyes Ears Nose & Paws Needs Your Help
item.description: A North Carolina organization delivers salvation on four legs.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: Student Opinion: Does Listening To an Audiobook Count as Reading?
item.description: Is it a valid way to consume literature or is it a kind of cheating?
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

media:content.media:credit: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times

item.title: What Jamaica Wants After Deadly Hurricane? Visit Us, Island Says.
item.description: Tourism accounts for nearly a third of Jamaica’s economy, so officials are rushing to reopen dozens of hotels in time to salvage the vital winter travel season.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Erin Schaff

media:content.media:description: Kellanie Kerr working by flashlight at a tourist shop this month in Negril, Jamaica.

item.title: On the Eve of Art Basel Miami Beach, a Case of the Jitters
item.description: Fourteen galleries pulled out of the fair this year, while others chose to stay and embrace the art fray. “It’s a good opportunity to be bold,” says one dealer.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol

media:content.media:credit: Martina Tuaty for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Inside the Miami Beach Convention Center, home of the annual Art Basel Miami Beach fair, December 2024.

item.title: With Judge's Ruling, a New Tool for Charging Crime in D.C.
item.description: The U.S. attorney’s office says it may use local grand juries for serious federal crime in Washington “when appropriate” after a judge signed off on the unusual procedure.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The E. Barrett Prettyman United States Court House in Washington.

item.title: People Are Ordering Smaller Pizzas and Fewer Toppings. What Does That Tell Us?
item.description: Sales are softening at big chains and independent shops aren’t selling as many extras. Competition, diet trends and consumer anxiety may all be playing a part.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jerry Carollo, the owner of Prima Pizza Kitchen in Somerville, N.J., said that customers used to regularly add drinks and sides to their pizza orders. But that is no longer the case.

item.title: Will a Once Glamorous Ship Become a Reef in Florida?
item.description: The S.S. United States was an opulent passenger steamship. Now it might be sunk in the Gulf of Mexico.
item.dc:creator: James Barron

media:content.media:description: The S.S. United States leaving New York on its first voyage to Europe in 1952.

item.title: NYT Games: How To Solve Pips
item.description: Level up your game with tips and strategies from expert solvers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Malave

item.title: ‘The Artist’ Blends Degas and Dollars, Murder and Mandy Patinkin
item.description: Created by Aram Rappaport for his streaming service, the Network, the historical drama explores the tensions, sometimes deadly, between art and commerce.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Graeber and Brian Karlsson

media:content.media:credit: Brian Karlsson for The New York Times

item.title: Miami Beach’s New Art Installation Frolics With the Fishes
item.description: Our critic explores “Reefline,” an underwater public sculpture park that hopes to be a haven for art and corals. But some skeptics question the scientific benefits.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: Despite Supreme Court Wins, Elite D.O.J. Unit Has Seen Mass Turnover
item.description: Even with an exodus of lawyers, the Office of the Solicitor General has had remarkable success. But fiery rhetoric and close White House ties have raised concerns.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle and Ann E. Marimow

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The solicitor general’s office, which has experienced mass departures, is focused on a single audience: the Supreme Court.

item.title: It’s a Homophobic Slur. What’s It Doing in So Much Theater?
item.description: “Prince Faggot,” “Figaro/Faggots” and other productions use the word to shock, provoke, reclaim it for gay men or all of the above. Does that make it OK?
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.category: The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Opera)
The Faggots and Their Friends Between Revolutions (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
